==See also== * [[Foreign policy of the United States]] * [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{U.S. Presidential Trips}} {{Ronald Reagan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International Presidential Trips Made By Reagan, Ronald}} [[Category:Presidency of Ronald Reagan]] [[Category:20th century in international relations]] [[Category:1980s politics-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of United States presidential visits]] [[Category:Geography-related lists]]

This is a list of European medieval [[marches]].
{{context|date=August 2015}}
==Northeastern marches== At the beginning of his rule as king of [[Germany]], [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto I]] tried to reorganize his realm to prepare an expansion to the East. At the beginning of the year 937, he created two marches: the March of the Billungen, given to [[Hermann Billung]], later [[Duke of Saxony]]; and the Eastern march, given to [[Gero]]. In 961, when Billung became Duke of Saxony, his March was merged with the duchy. In the case of Gero, Otto I, now emperor, decided the division of his territories, greatly expanded since 937.
* [[March of Billung]] (937-961): Carved from the Duchy of Saxony, then merged back. ** 937-961: Hermann Billung * [[Danish March]], German buffer zone against the [[Danes (Germanic tribe)|Danes]] * [[March of Gero]], sometimes called Nordmark or Ostmark (937-965). Carved from the Duchy of Saxony, then divided in five marches. ** 937-965: Gero * [[Northern March|Nordmark]], later known as [[March of Brandenburg]] (from 965): Carved from the March of Gero. ** 965-985: [[Dietrich von Haldensleben]] ** 985-1003: [[Lothar I of Walbeck]] * [[Saxon Eastern March|Ostmark]], sometime confused with Nordmark, or with the Bavarian Ostmark (Austria), later the [[Margraviate of Lusatia]] (from 965). Carved from the March of Gero. ** 965-979: [[Thietmar I]] ** 979-993: [[Hodo I]] ** 993-1015: [[Gero II]] * [[March of Meissen|Meissen]], also called March of Thuringia (from 965). Carved from the March of Gero. ** 965-979: [[Wigbert]] ** 979-985: [[Rikdag]] ** 985-1002: [[Ekkehard I]] * [[March of Merseburg|Merseburg]] (965-982). Carved from the March of Gero, annexed to Meissen. ** 965-982: [[Gunther, Margrave of Merseburg|Günther]] * [[March of Zeitz|Zeitz]] (965-979). Carved from the March of Gero, annexed to Meissen. ** 965-979: [[Wigger I]] * [[Margraviate of Landsberg|Landsberg]] (1261–1347), separated from Lusatia, integrated into Meissen (later Saxony). * [[March of Moravia]] (1182-1918). Created by [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor]].
==Northwestern marches== In 861, [[Charles the Bald]], king of France, created two marches to protect his realm from warriors coming from Brittany and Normandy. Both were named [[March of Neustria]], but will be known as March of Brittany and March of Normandy. In 863, the king created the March of Flanders.
* [[March of Brittany]] (861-987): Annexed to the Kingdom of France. ** 861-866: [[Robert the Strong]] * [[March of Normandy]] (861-987): Annexed to the Kingdom of France. ** 861-865: [[Adalard the Seneschal|Adalhard]], [[Udo of Neustria]] and [[Berengar I of Neustria]] (jointly) * [[County of Flanders|March of Flanders]] (863-877): Downgraded to a County afterwards. ** 863-877: [[Baldwin I, Count of Flanders|Baldwin I]]
Three marches belonging to the Holy Roman Empire were created in the [[Low Countries]]: * [[Margraviate of Antwerp|March of Antwerp]] (974-1190): Became part of the [[Duchy of Brabant]]. * [[Ename|March of Ename]] (974-1033): Captured by [[Baldwin IV, Count of Flanders]] and became [[County of Flanders|Imperial Flanders]]. * [[Valenciennes|March of Valenciennes]] (974-1071): Became part of the [[County of Hainaut]].
==Southeastern marches== * [[March of Austria|Ostmark]], later raised to a duchy; became known as Austria. * [[March of Styria|Styria]], later raised to a duchy. * [[March of Carinthia|Carinthia]] (889-1012), later a duchy. ** ''[[Mark an der Sann]]'', later the [[County of Cilli]], then integrated into Styria. ** ''[[Mark an der Drau]]''; later integrated into Styria. * [[March of Friuli|Friuli]] (776-927) * [[March of Carniola|Carniola]] (927-1071): carved from Friuli, annexed to the Patriarchy of Aquileia. Later formed part of the [[Habsburg monarchy|Habsburg domains]] before being raised to a duchy. ** [[Windic March]], a region of the March of Carniola * [[March of Istria|Istria]] (1062-1209): carved from Carinthia, annexed to the Patriarchate of Aquileia. * [[March of Verona|Verona]] (1061-1250): created by the Emperor as a gift, annexed to Austria. * [[March of Tuscany|Tuscany]] (931-1173): created by the Italian king [[Hugh of Arles]] for his brother, then annexed to the Empire. ** 931-936: [[Boso of Tuscany]] * [[Margravate of Mantua|Mantua]] (1433–1530) * [[March of Ivrea|Ivrea]] (888-1015): created by [[Guy III of Spoleto]]
==Southwestern marches== * [[Marca Hispanica|Spanish March]], also named Gothia and Septimania (806-885): Created to protect Frankish heartland from [[Al-Andalus]] invasions, merged into Aquitaine. ** 806-816: [[Beggo of Paris]] ** 820-825: [[Rampon, Count of Barcelona]] ** 826-832: [[Bernard of Septimania]] ** 832-835: [[Berengar von Toulouse]] ** 835-844: Bernard of Septimania *[[Upper March]] (''al-Tagr al-A'la al-Andalusi''), centered on [[Zaragoza]]: created to protect the [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Emirate of Cordoba]] from Frankish coastal and east-Pyrenees invasions. The northernmost part of the Upper March was called the Distant or Farthest March (''al-Tagr al-Aqsa'') *Middle March (''al-Tagr al-Awsat''), centered on [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] and later [[Medinaceli]]: created to protect the Emirate of Cordoba from invasions from the west-Pyrenees and [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. *[[Lower March]] (''al-Tagr al-Adna''), centered on [[Mérida, Spain|Mérida]]: created to protect the Emirate of Cordoba from Asturian incursions. *[[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], named for the fortifications typical of a march: created to protect the Asturian kingdom from Cordoban invasions. It developed into a county, then a kingdom. * [[Margrave of Provence|Provence]] (905-1105): From 975 it became a family title, the eldest bearing it. It disappeared after the death of Raymond IV of Toulouse. ** 905-936: [[Hugh of Italy]] ** 936-948: [[Hugh, Duke of Burgundy]] ** 948-975: [[Conrad of Burgundy]] ** 975-993: [[William I of Provence]] ** 993-1005: [[Rotbold II of Provence]] ** 1005-1014: [[Rotbold III of Provence]] ** 1014-1037: [[William III of Provence]] ** 1037-1051: [[Fulk Bertrand of Provence]] ** 1051-1061: [[Geoffrey I of Provence]] ** 1061-1094: [[William Bertrand of Provence]] ** 1094-1105: [[Raymond IV of Toulouse]] * Aquitaine (885-886): Successor to the Spanish March, became a Duchy. ** [[Bernard Plantapilosa]]
==English marches== * [[Welsh Marches]] * [[Scottish Marches]]
==March as modern-era regional toponym== * [[Altmark|Altmark (Old March)]], region in northern Saxony-Anhalt * [[Altmarkkreis Salzwedel]], district of Saxony-Anhalt * [[Denmark]], a sovereign state * [[Finnmark]], a [[counties of Norway|county of Norway]] *[[Friuli Venezia Giulia]], a [[regions of Italy|region of Italy]] combining the former regions of [[Friuli]] and Venezia Giulia, known in English as the [[Julian March]] * [[Grenzmark Posen-West Prussia]], [[Provinces of Prussia|province of Prussia]] (1922–1938) * [[Hedmark]], a [[counties of Norway|county of Norway]] * [[Kurmark|Kurmark (Electoral March)]], former expression for a region in today's western Brandenburg * [[Lappmarken]], a region and former governorate in northern Sweden * [[Brandenburg|March of Brandenburg]] (colloquial, but not official), [[States of Germany|state of Germany]] * [[Marche]], [[region of Italy]] * [[Mittelmark|Mittelmark (Middle March)]], region in central Brandenburg * [[Pomarkku|Pomarkku (Påmark)]], a municipality of Finland * [[Potsdam-Mittelmark]], district of Brandenburg * [[New March]], former expression for a region in western Poland * [[Telemark]], a [[counties of Norway|county of Norway]] * [[Uckermark]], a region in northeastern Brandenburg and southern [[Vorpommern]] * [[Uckermark (district)]], a district of Brandenburg
==See also== * [[Commandery (China)|Commandery]] (''jùn''), the equivalent Chinese territory
[[Category:Marquesses| ]] [[Category:Europe-related lists]] [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:Marches (country subdivision)]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Marches}}

page.title: List of political and geographic subdivisions by total area from 200,000 to 500,000 square kilometers
List of reportedly haunted locations in South Africa

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of reportedly haunted locations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text: [[File:Castle of GH 1.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Castle of Good Hope]]]] [[File:Erasmus kasteel (2).JPG|thumb|200px|[[Erasmus Castle]]]] The following is a list of reportedly haunted locations in South Africa. ==Haunted locations== *'''[[Castle of Good Hope]]''': This 17th-century [[Dutch East India Company]] fort in [[Cape Town]] is believed to be the most haunted site in [[South Africa]]. The resident ghosts reportedly include the ghost of [[Lady Anne Barnard]] who lived there, the ghost of a soldier who hanged himself in the bell tower and the ghosts of soldiers pacing the [[battlement]]s.{{cite book|last1=Hopkins|first1=Pat|title=Ghosts of South Africa|date=2006|publisher=Zebra Press|location=Cape Town|isbn=9781770073036|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=qVA6zfB-LCUC|accessdate=17 June 2014}}{{rp|18–28}}{{cite news|last1=Peters |first1=Melanie |title=Ghosts haunt guards at Cape Town Castle |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/ghosts-haunt-guards-at-cape-town-castle-1.63293#.U59SEJSSyyg |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=IOL |date=30 March 2001 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNjBjv0F?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/ghosts-haunt-guards-at-cape-town-castle-1.63293 |archivedate=16 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|last1=Jackman |first1=Rebecca |title=Inside SA's most haunted site |url=http://www.iol.co.za/travel/south-africa/western-cape/inside-sa-s-most-haunted-site-1.1550960#.U59OnZSSyyg |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=Weekend Argus |date=23 July 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNiswNKy?url=http://www.iol.co.za/travel/south-africa/western-cape/inside-sa-s-most-haunted-site-1.1550960 |archivedate=16 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} *'''[[Erasmus Castle]]/Kasteel''': "Die Spookhuis" or Erasmus Castle in [[Erasmuskloof, Pretoria]], local residents often report strange noises and ghost sightings in and around the Victorian mansion. Paranormal activity includes lit windows in the uninhabited mansion, and hearing people moaning at night.{{cite web|url=http://boksburghistorical.com/index_files/BHAaug2004.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-09-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304120538/http://boksburghistorical.com/index_files/BHAaug2004.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }} * '''[[Fort Frederick, Eastern Cape|Fort Frederick]]''': In [[Eastern Cape]], is a fort built by the British during 1799 in Algoa Bay that is reportedly haunted by theatrical ghosts of a Shakespearian play.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=qVA6zfB-LCUC&pg=PA170&lpg=PA170&dq=fort+frederick+rsa&source=bl&ots=-juAEkyq5i&sig=NcTcDN5-9sWis3g2HohsgLcAV60&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwB2oVChMIquuP9J-fyAIVSpeUCh1eNgLr#v=onepage&q=fort%20frederick%20rsa&f=false|title=Ghosts of South Africa|publisher=}} *'''Foxwood House''' in [[Johannesburg]]. Paranormal activity includes mysterious footsteps and visitors seeing an anonymous spectral woman with an anonymous child on the balcony of this building.{{cite web|url=http://www.getaway.co.za/travel-ideas/places-to.../south-africas-haunted-hotels/|title=7 of South Africa's best haunted hotels - Getaway Magazine|work=Getaway Magazine}} *'''Kempton Park Hospital''': This abandoned hospital in [[Kempton Park, Gauteng]] is frequented by thrill-seekers and [[Ghost hunting|ghost hunters]].{{cite news|last1=Theresa |first1=Taylor |title=Ghosts that haunt the old hospital |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/gauteng/ghosts-that-haunt-the-old-hospital-1.1084828#.U59cfJSSyyg |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=The Star |date=17 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNmEDm4C?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/gauteng/ghosts-that-haunt-the-old-hospital-1.1084828 |archivedate=16 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|last1=Bester|first1=Zianko|title=Something strange in your neighbourhood? Call Gauteng Paranormal Society|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=60172&CatID=12|accessdate=18 June 2014|work=The New Age|date=24 August 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140618150105/http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=60172&CatID=12|archivedate=18 June 2014|deadurl=no}} *'''Nottingham Road Hotel''': A hotel in [[KwaZulu-Natal]], where the ghost of a former barmaid is said to still wander the hotel moving pots, light fixtures, and sheets, as well as ringing the service bell.{{rp|174–175}}[http://www.articlesphere.com/Article/Scary-Creatures-of-the-Night--Scariest-Hotels-in-the-World/165029 Nottingham Road Hotel] from Articlesphere.com * '''[[Old Presidency]]''': In [[Bloemfontein]], was the official residence of the former [[Orange Free State]]. The stables at the back of the building are thought to be haunted with several reports of people hearing carriages moving into the stables. The premises reportedly house the ghost of a dog with many people hearing ephemeral barking at night. There are also many stories of children being spotted within the building due to the buildings tenure as a school and hostel.{{cite web|url=http://www.joemynhardt.com/blog/the-haunting-of-the-old-presidency-ou-presidensie-|title=The Haunting of the Old Presidency (Ou Presidensie)|publisher=}} *'''[[Somerset Hospital (Cape Town)|Somerset Hospital]]''': South Africa's oldest hospital in [[Green Point, Cape Town]], where resident ghosts reportedly include Sister [[Henrietta Stockdale]], a blonde girl combing her hair and others that roam the corridors at night.{{rp|157}}{{cite news|last1=Lovell |first1=Jeremy |title=Cape Town markets its ghostly history |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/cape-town-markets-its-ghostly-history-1.55734#.U6BATpSSyyg |accessdate=17 June 2014 |date=10 December 2000 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QOnxygGr?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/cape-town-markets-its-ghostly-history-1.55734 |archivedate=17 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==See also== *[[List of reportedly haunted locations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Ghosts|state=expanded}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haunted locations in the world}} [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of reportedly haunted locations]]

page.title: List of selected stars for navigation

revision.text:
[[File:DN-SD-03-08769.JPEG|thumb|right|The selected stars for navigation are often used for [[sextant observation]]s.]] Fifty-eight selected navigational [[star]]s are given a special status in the field of [[celestial navigation]]. Of the approximately 6,000 stars visible to the [[naked eye]] under optimal conditions, the selected stars are among the brightest and span 38 [[constellation]]s of the [[celestial sphere]] from the [[declination]] of −70° to +89°. Many of the selected stars were named in [[Ancient history|antiquity]] by the [[Babylonia]]ns, Greeks, Romans, and Arabs. The star [[Polaris]], often called the "North Star", is treated specially due to its proximity to the north [[celestial pole]]. When navigating in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], special techniques can be used with Polaris to determine [[latitude]] or [[gyrocompass]] error. The other 57 selected stars have daily positions given in [[nautical almanac]]s, aiding the [[second mate|navigator]] in efficiently performing observations on them. A second group of 115 "tabulated stars" can also be used for celestial navigation, but are often less familiar to the navigator and require extra calculations. For purposes of identification, the positions of navigational stars — expressed as declination and [[sidereal hour angle]] — are often rounded to the nearest degree. In addition to tables, [[star chart]]s provide an aid to the navigator in identifying the navigational stars, showing [[constellation]]s, relative positions, and brightness. ==Background== [[File:Nautical almanac left-hand page.png|thumb|right|Selected navigation stars (except Polaris) listed on a [[Nautical almanac|U.S. Nautical Almanac]] page for May 1995]] Under optimal conditions, approximately 6,000 stars are visible to the naked eye of an observer on Earth.Bowditch, 2002, p. 249. Of these, 58 stars are known in the field of navigational astronomy as "selected stars", including 19 stars of the first magnitude, 38 stars of the second magnitude, and [[Polaris]]. The selection of the stars is made by [[Her Majesty's Nautical Almanac Office]] and the [[US Naval Observatory]], in the production of the yearly ''[[Nautical Almanac]]'' which the two organizations have published jointly since 1958.{{cite web |title =History of the Nautical Almanac |publisher=US Naval Observatory |url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/astronomical-applications/publications/hist-naut-almanac |accessdate = 2011-01-23}} Criteria in the choice of stars includes their distribution across the celestial sphere, brightness, and ease of identification.Wright and Whitney, 1992, p. 273. Information for another 115 stars, known as "tabulated stars", is also available to the navigator. This list provides information on the name, approximate position in the celestial sphere, and [[apparent magnitude]] of the 58 selected stars in tabular form and by star charts. These stars are typically used in two ways by the navigator. The first is to obtain a [[line of position]] by use of a [[sextant]] observation and the techniques of celestial navigation.Bowditch, 2002, pp. 301–303. Multiple lines of position can be intersected to obtain a position known as a celestial fix. The second typical use of the navigational stars is to determine gyrocompass error by computing the [[azimuth]] of a star and comparing it to an azimuth measured using the ship's gyrocompass.Bowditch, 2002, pp. 271–274. Numerous other applications also exist. Navigators typically refer to stars using one of two naming systems for stars: common names and [[Bayer's Name|Bayer's designations]]. All of the selected stars have had a common name since 1953, and many were named in antiquity by the Arabs, Greeks, Romans, and Babylonians. Bayer's naming convention has been in use since 1603, and consists of a Greek letter combined with the possessive form of the star's constellation. Both names are shown for each star in the tables and charts below. Each star's approximate position on the celestial sphere is given using the [[equatorial coordinate system]]. The celestial sphere is an imaginary globe of infinite size with the Earth at its center.Bowditch, 2002, p. 234. Positions on the celestial sphere are often expressed using two coordinates: [[declination]] and sidereal hour angle, which are similar to latitude and [[longitude]] on the surface of the Earth. To define declination, the Earth's [[equator]] is projected out to the celestial sphere to construct the [[celestial equator]], and declination is measured in degrees north or south of this celestial equator. Sidereal hour angle is a measurement between 0° and 360°, indicating how far west a body is from an arbitrarily chosen point on the celestial sphere called the ''[[March equinox|First Point of Aries]]''. Note that right ascension, as used by astronomers, is 360° minus the sidereal hour angle. The final characteristic provided in the tables and star charts is the star's brightness, expressed in terms of apparent magnitude. Magnitude is a logarithmic scale of brightness, designed so that a body of one magnitude is approximately 2.512 times brighter than a body of the next magnitude.The value is actually the fifth root of 100, an [[irrational number]] known as [[Pogson's Ratio]]. See {{cite book |title=Teaching Science |volume=52–53 |author= |date=2006 |publisher=Australian Science Teachers' Association |page=44 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ae0kAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Pogson's+Ratio%22+irrational+number&dq=%22Pogson's+Ratio%22+irrational+number&hl=en&ei=fwCFTI-8A8TYnAedib1i&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA |accessdate=2010-09-06}}Bowditch, 2002, p. 219. Thus, a body of magnitude 1 is 2.5125, or 100 times brighter than a body of magnitude 6. The dimmest stars that can be seen through a 200 inch terrestrial telescope are of the 20th magnitude, and very bright objects like the Sun and a full Moon have magnitudes of −26.7 and −12.6 respectively.{{clear}} ==Table== {| class="wikitable" width="50%" style="float:right;" ! style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | '''Key to the table''' |- ! style="text-align: center; center;" | '''Column title''' ! style="text-align: center;" | '''Description''' |- | align ="center"| No. | The number used to identify stars in navigation publications and star charts.This list uses the assigned numbers from the [[nautical almanac]], which includes only 57 stars. Polaris, which is included in the list given in ''The American Practical Navigator'', is listed here without a number. |- |style="text-align: center;" | Common name | The name of the star commonly used navigation publications and star charts. |- |style="text-align: center;" | [[Bayer designation]] | Another name of the star which combines a [[Greek alphabet|Greek letter]] with the possessive form of its constellation's [[Latin language|Latin]] name. |- |style="text-align: center;" | Etymology of
common name | Etymology of the common name.Bowditch, 2002, p. 248. |- |style="text-align: center;" | SHA | [[hour angle|Sidereal hour angle (SHA)]], the angular distance west of the [[vernal equinox]]. |- |style="text-align: center;" | Dec. | [[Declination]], the angular distance north or south of the [[celestial equator]]. |- |style="text-align: center;" | [[Apparent magnitude|App.
magnitude]] | Apparent magnitude, an indicator of the star's brightness. |} The table of navigational stars provides several types of information. In the first column is the identifying index number, followed by the common name, the Bayer designation, and the etymology of the common name. Then the star's approximate position, suitable for identification purposes, is given in terms of declination and sidereal hour angle, followed by the star's magnitude. The final column presents citations to the sources of the data, ''The American Practical Navigator'' and the star's entry at the [[SIMBAD]] database, a project of the [[Centre de données astronomiques de Strasbourg|Strasbourg Astronomical Data Center]] or CDS. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:99%" ! width="20" scope="col" | No. ! width="30" scope="col" | Common

charts== {| class="wikitable" width="50%" style="float:right;" ! style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | '''Key to the Star charts''' |- ! style="text-align: center;" | '''Item''' ! style="text-align: center;" | '''Description''' |- |style="text-align: center;" | UPPERCASE TEXT |Constellation names are indicated in uppercase text. |- |[[File:Nav-icon-sel-mag-1.5.svg|32px|center|alt=star of magnitude 1.5 and brighter]] |Selected star of magnitude 1.5 and brighter. Labeled with common name, star number, and Greek letter to indicate Bayer designation. |- |[[File:Nav-icon-sel-mag-1.6.svg|32px|center|alt=star of magnitude 1.6 and fainter]] |Selected star of magnitude 1.6 and fainter. Labeled with common name, star number, and Greek letter to indicate Bayer designation. |- |[[File:Nav-icon-tab-mag-2.5.svg|32px|center|alt=star of magnitude 2.5 and brighter]] |Tabulated star of magnitude 2.5 and brighter. Labeled with Greek letter to indicate Bayer designation. |- |[[File:Nav-icon-tab-mag-2.6.svg|32px|center|alt=star of magnitude 2.6 and fainter]] |Tabulated star of magnitude 2.6 and fainter. Labeled with Greek letter to indicate Bayer designation. |- |[[File:Nav-icon-untab.svg|32px|center|alt=untabulated star]] |Untabulated star. Not labeled. |- |style="text-align: center;" |Dotted line |Constellation outline. |} Navigators often use [[star chart]]s to identify a star by its position relative to other stars. References like the ''Nautical Almanac'' and ''The American Practical Navigator'' provide four star charts, covering different portions of the celestial sphere. Two of these charts are [[azimuthal equidistant projection]]s of the north and south poles. The other two cover the equatorial region of the celestial sphere, from the declination of 30° south to 30° north. The two equatorial charts are [[mercator projection]]s, one for the eastern hemisphere of the celestial sphere and one for the western hemisphere. Note that unlike familiar maps, east is shown to the left and west is shown to the right. With this orientation, the navigator can hold the star chart overhead, and the arrangement of the stars on the chart will resemble the stars in the sky. In the star charts, constellations are labelled with capital letters and indicated by dotted lines collecting their stars. The 58 selected stars for navigation are shown in blue and labelled with their common name, star number, and a Greek letter to indicate their Bayer designation. The additional 115 tabulated stars that can also be used for navigation are shown in red and labelled with a Greek letter to indicate their Bayer designation. Some additional stars not suitable for navigation are also included on the charts to indicate constellations, they are presented as unlabelled small red dots. ===Equatorial stars=== ; '''Equatorial stars of the eastern hemisphere''' The equatorial region of the celestial sphere's eastern hemisphere includes 16 navigational stars from Alpheratz in the constellation Andromeda to Denebola in Leo. It also includes stars from the constellations Cetus, Aries, Taurus, Orion, Canis Major and Minor, Gemini, and Hydra. Of particular note among these stars are "the dog star" Sirius, the brightest star in the sky, and four stars of the easily identified constellation Orion.{{clear}} Image:Bowditch-equatorial-stars-180-360.svg|center|600px|alt=Equatorial stars with SHA from 180 to 360| rect 767 236 803 264 [[#4|Diphda (#4) SHA 349 Dec. It also includes stars from the constellations Virgo, Bootes, Libra, Corona Borealis, Scorpio, Ophiuchus, Sagittarius, and Aquila. The [[variable star]] Arcturus is the brightest star in this group.{{clear}} Image:Bowditch-equatorial-stars-0-180.svg|center|600px|alt=Equatorial stars with SHA from 0 to 180| rect 812 240 829 265 [[#29|Geinah (#29) SHA 165 Dec. They are listed in order of decreasing sidereal hour angle, or from the [[vernal equinox]] westward across the sky. Starting with Schedar in the constellation Cassiopeia, the list includes stars from the constellations Auriga, the Great and Little Bears, Draco, Lyra and Cygnus. The two brightest northern stars are Vega and Capella. In the star chart to the right, declination is shown by the radial coordinate, starting at 90° north in the center and decreasing to 30° north at the outer edge. Sidereal hour angle is shown as the angular coordinate, starting at 0° at the left of the chart, and increasing counter-clockwise.{{clear}} ===Southern stars=== Image:Navigational-stars-below-30-degrees-south.svg|float|right|400px|alt=Southern navigational stars| rect 351 191 379 218 [[#2|Ankaa (#2) SHA 354 Dec. S 30]] desc top-right The 18 southern stars are those with a declination between 30° south and 90° south. They are listed in order of decreasing sidereal hour angle, or from the [[vernal equinox]] westward across the sky. Starting with Ankaa in the constellation Phoenix, the list includes stars from the constellations Eridanus, Carina, Crux, Centaurus, Libra, Triangulum Australe, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Pavo, and Grus. Canopus, Rigil Kentaurus, Achernar, and Hadar are the brightest stars in the southern sky. In the star chart to the right, declination is shown by the radial coordinate, starting at 90° south in the center and decreasing to 30° south at the outer edge. Sidereal hour angle is shown as the angular coordinate, starting at 0° at the right of the chart, and increasing clockwise.{{clear}} ==Footnotes== ;; '''Notes''' {{Reflist|group=Note}} ;; '''Citations''' {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==References== *{{cite book | first = Nathaniel | last = Bowditch, LL.D. | authorlink = Nathaniel Bowditch | title = The American Practical Navigator: An Epitome of Navigation | publisher = [[National Imagery and Mapping Agency]] | url = http://www.1yachtua.com/nauticalcharts/downloads/Practical_navigator.pdf | date = 2002 | origyear = 1802 | location= Bethesda, MD | isbn = 0-939837-54-4 | chapter = 15: Navigational Astronomy | page= | ref=Bowditch2002 | accessdate=2016-09-20 }} *{{cite web | url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/ | title =SIMBAD | author =Strasbourg Astronomical Data Center (CDS) | authorlink =Centre de Données astronomiques de Strasbourg | date = 2010 | work =Set of Identifications, Measurements, and Bibliography for Astronomical Data | publisher =University of Strasbourg | location =Strasbourg |trans-title=| accessdate = 2010-09-05 | quote = | ref = }} *{{cite book |author=United States Army Research Office |title=2010 Nautical Almanac |publisher=Paradise Cay Publications |location=Arcata, CA |date=2009 |pages=28, leaf |isbn=0-939837-85-4 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} *{{cite book |author1=Wright, Frances |author2=Whitney, Charles Allen |title=Learn to navigate by the tutorial system developed at Harvard |publisher=Cornell Maritime Press |location=Cambridge, Md |date=1992 |pages=|isbn=0-87033-426-3 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} {{Lists of stars}} {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Navigational Stars}} [[Category:Celestial navigation|Stars]] [[Category:Lists of stars|Navigation]] [[Category:Navigation]]
